messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 52 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Concise tensors of minimal border rank

Paper Abstract: Abstract. We determine defining equations for the set of concise tensors of minimal border rank in ‚ÑÇm‚Äã‚äó‚Äã‚ÑÇm‚Äã‚äó‚Äã‚ÑÇmsuperscript‚ÑÇùëötensor-productsuperscript‚ÑÇùëötensor-productsuperscript‚ÑÇùëö\mathbb{C}^{m}{\mathord{\otimes}}\mathbb{C}^{m}{\mathord{\otimes}}\mathbb{C}^{m} when m=5ùëö5m=5 and the set of concise minimal border rank 1‚àósubscript11_{*}-generic tensors when m=5,6ùëö56m=5,6. We solve the classical problem in algebraic complexity theory of classifying minimal border rank tensors in the special case m=5ùëö5m=5. Our proofs utilize two recent developments: the 111-equations defined by Buczy≈Ñska-Buczy≈Ñski and results of Jelisiejew-≈†ivic on the variety of commuting matrices. We introduce a new algebraic invariant of a concise tensor, its 111-algebra, and exploit it to give a strengthening of Friedland‚Äôs normal form for 111-degenerate tensors satisfying Strassen‚Äôs equations. We use the 111-algebra to characterize wild minimal border rank tensors and classify them in ‚ÑÇ5‚Äã‚äó‚Äã‚ÑÇ5‚Äã‚äó‚Äã‚ÑÇ5superscript‚ÑÇ5tensor-productsuperscript‚ÑÇ5tensor-productsuperscript‚ÑÇ5\mathbb{C}^{5}{\mathord{\otimes}}\mathbb{C}^{5}{\mathord{\otimes}}\mathbb{C}^{5}.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 52 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 52"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "A refined laser method and faster matrix multiplication",
        "Fast matrix multiplication: limitations of the Coppersmith-Winograd method (extended abstract)",
        "Construction of instantons",
        "Primitive spaces of matrices of bounded rank. II",
        "Primitive spaces of matrices of bounded rank",
        "Toward a salmon conjecture",
        "Bilinear maps on Artinian modules",
        "On the growth of the Hilbert function of a module",
        "On degeneration of tensors and algebras",
        "Slice Rank of Block Tensors and Irreversibility of Structure Tensors of Algebras",
        "On differences between the border rank and the smoothable rank of a polynomial",
        "Secant varieties to high degree Veronese reembeddings, catalecticant matrices and smoothable Gorenstein schemes",
        "Apolarity, border rank, and multigraded Hilbert scheme",
        "Finite schemes and secant varieties over arbitrary characteristic",
        "On the third secant variety",
        "Algebraic complexity theory",
        "Hilbert schemes of 8 points",
        "Irreducibility of the Gorenstein loci of Hilbert schemes via ray families",
        "Tensors with maximal symmetries",
        "New lower bounds for matrix mulitplication and det3subscriptdet3\\operatorname{det}_{3}",
        "Matrix multiplication via arithmetic progressions",
        "Barriers for rank methods in arithmetic complexity",
        "Fundamental algebraic geometry",
        "On tensors of border rank lùëôl in ‚ÑÇm√ón√ólsuperscript‚ÑÇùëöùëõùëô\\mathbb{C}^{m\\times n\\times l}",
        "A proof of the set-theoretic version of the salmon conjecture",
        "Vector bundles give equations of cactus varieties",
        "Algebraic geometry of Bayesian networks",
        "On dominance and varieties of commuting matrices",
        "A note on commuting pairs of matrices",
        "Vanishing Hessian, wild forms and their border VSP",
        "Power sums, Gorenstein algebras, and determinantal loci",
        "Varieties of reductions for ùî§‚Äãùî©nùî§subscriptùî©ùëõ{\\mathfrak{gl}}_{n}",
        "Versal deformations and local Hilbert schemes",
        "Components and singularities of Quot schemes and varieties of commuting matrices",
        "Geometry and complexity theory",
        "Generalizations of Strassen‚Äôs equations for secant varieties of Segre varieties",
        "Abelian tensors",
        "On the ideals and singularities of secant varieties of Segre varieties",
        "Secant varieties and the complexity of matrix multiplication",
        "New lower bounds for the border rank of matrix multiplication",
        "Powers of tensors and fast matrix multiplication",
        "Generic finite schemes and Hochschild cocycles",
        "Symplectic bundles on the plane, secant varieties and L√ºroth quartics revisited",
        "Isomorphism types of commutative algebras of finite rank over an algebraically closed field",
        "On the rank of a symmetric form",
        "On the complexity of matrix multiplication",
        "Rank and optimal computation of generic tensors",
        "Relative bilinear complexity and matrix multiplication",
        "Elementary introduction to representable functors and Hilbert schemes",
        "Perestanovochnye matritsy",
        "Breaking the Coppersimith-Winograd barrier",
        "Irreversibility of structure tensors of modules"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 52 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Concise tensors of minimal border rank, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
